body: I strongly suspect this is the same as #3294 which #3314 and #3315 should help with.  Will be testing that out today and will let you know.
That is for the slow response - not finding validators is probably a different thing which is a bit surprising and need further investigation.

I started up my pyrmont node and ran the exact above command (except I ran it on 'localhost:5051) and got a response:

`{
    "data": [
        {
            "balance": "32004403974",
            "index": "101321",
            "status": "active_ongoing",
            "validator": {
                "activation_eligibility_epoch": "320",
                "activation_epoch": "650",
                "effective_balance": "32000000000",
                "exit_epoch": "18446744073709551615",
                "pubkey": "0xa907553268176c3517a732b2525a04d89bfd83aa9df28b69fedd1998413f49a4c3319ac8c265ce8247544982df560e94",
                "slashed": false,
                "withdrawable_epoch": "18446744073709551615",
                "withdrawal_credentials": "0x0010361af430aa7ab4a9567eaaca50ec5e02315ca1513d9ee8d73bde96370091"
            }
        },
        {
            "balance": "32001569569",
            "index": "101681",
            "status": "active_ongoing",
            "validator": {
                "activation_eligibility_epoch": "489",
                "activation_epoch": "740",
                "effective_balance": "32000000000",
                "exit_epoch": "18446744073709551615",
                "pubkey": "0xa3f5cfa04c61610c89528c2eaccc7bc325882f1a4ec9b20c74ce366b6e5b1ec3b2a0d2758c38d8dd4479f45a1118379c",
                "slashed": false,
                "withdrawable_epoch": "18446744073709551615",
                "withdrawal_credentials": "0x0010361af430aa7ab4a9567eaaca50ec5e02315ca1513d9ee8d73bde96370091"
            }
        }
    ]
}
curl   0.00s user 0.01s system 0% cpu 8.723 total`

interesting note on the 'lighthouse' output, is the status 'active' isn't one of the valid responses for a status, unless that's changed since we implemented...

I'll dig into the timings.
After restarting teku it now picks up the validators.  As for the different statuses, that's lighthouse following https://github.com/ethereum/eth2.0-APIs/pull/94 which hasn't been merged.
Was there an exception in the logs when it produced no output by any chance?
Afraid not, logs are clear of exceptions for the time I was testing this.

the only way i could see an empty response with no exceptions would be if head was prior to slot 320 at the time...

The above PR's look to have helped regarding response time, but converting and validating the keys is still a relatively slow process...
Given that it's responding with data now, is the response time of lower importance?

I'll keep an eye out and see if the missing validators occurs again.

Regarding the response time: it's a problem because I need to find out the indices for a number of potential validators.  The fact that the number of validators is limited by URL size means that there are repeated calls, and each call is taking around 10s, so I can easily be waiting for a few minutes on startup which isn't ideal.

it's a big list with just 8 responses, you would get a huge speed increase if you were to just include the 8 validators that are valid...

It has to map all of the keys to the BLSKey, which is a lot slower than reading a hex string, and then search for them through the state.

In the above case, if i just do:
`time curl 'http://localhost:5051/eth/v1/beacon/states/head/validators?id=0xa907553268176c3517a732b2525a04d89bfd83aa9df28b69fedd1998413f49a4c3319ac8c265ce8247544982df560e94,0xa3f5cfa04c61610c89528c2eaccc7bc325882f1a4ec9b20c74ce366b6e5b1ec3b2a0d2758c38d8dd4479f45a1118379c,0x80f4bba063d46be2baf272d62887eb9dd8a1148891dfde75c39509fa5cf527de96fac2665f412efb5e3bc6f04edef008,0x9571308b62b409c0d8ce6d8167b2b395e372f50461babd88e7fde61fd3de66b9bf97caa39693fbc27c9ae8cdc853dcfc,0xa29544314c7b5f963f0447aae121d5b46c9e8438d25cc8de58c3eccdef2e6124494551870f63e69dc2750594d0e6c6ba,0xa32a3ca1f70d3cc2de4c0bdfe09af430de97ad44842dc05a95b8786f877795c5e420d5fe6766e36752626f34d7d58d7d,0x8c82fd6ae8940a75e2956fcdc0938134c6579fdde79a9c8b905256248d9f7a819fe423048ae32693f777c107c60aa31b,0xa7da4551215b3088ac7d9bd48254c4a42d24790b727baa9eb05f90c10e88f588ea013c76e631508d666a0b8ca252150a'

real	0m0.008s
user	0m0.006s
sys	0m0.000s
`

I ran this a few times, the worst i saw was 0.03S, so the 'missing' keys are at a huge cost to convert. Not sure if this is helpful information but it does help show context hopefully...
For direct comparison, the entire original set was 
`real	0m8.672s
user	0m0.005s
sys	0m0.004s
`
on the same machine.

> it's a big list with just 8 responses, you would get a huge speed increase if you were to just include the 8 validators that are valid...

The problem is that I don't know which keys are valid without querying for them.  And those that aren't valid one epoch may be valid the next, as the relevant deposits kick in, so a negative result for one epoch doesn't help for the next.

No chance of the map key being either a string or simple byte array, rather than actual BLS public keys?
We'll look into speeding it up, I'm just not confident to commit to when it'll be fast... There's some async discussions that are happening, will keep you updated...
